description:
Acanthopagrus schlegelii, commonly known as the blackhead seabream or Schlegel's black porgy, is a species of marine fish belonging to the family Sparidae. It is native to the western Pacific Ocean, found in coastal waters of Japan, Korea, China, and Taiwan.

The Acanthopagrus schlegelii is a medium-sized fish, typically reaching lengths of around 30 cm. It has a deep, compressed body with a distinctive black spot on the head, which gives it the common name "blackhead seabream." The fish has a terminal mouth with small, incisor-like teeth that are adapted for grazing on benthic algae and small invertebrates.

This species is an important commercial and recreational fish, commonly found in local markets and targeted by anglers. It typically inhabits nearshore reefs, rocky areas, and seagrass beds, where it feeds on a variety of marine organisms. Acanthopagrus schlegelii plays a significant role in the coastal ecosystems of its native range, contributing to the overall biodiversity and functioning of these marine environments.
